title: There may be trouble ahead: New Commission’s Parliament test
text:
No sooner had Ursula von der Leyen presented her Commission team than she rushed away to deal with her next big challenge: convincing the European Parliament to back her.

On Tuesday afternoon, she met for several hours with the leaders of the main political groups in the Parliament, whose support her picks will need before they can take office — including several who have already been earmarked as potentially in trouble.

Von der Leyen spent time with Manfred Weber of the conservative European People’s Party, Iratxe García from the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, and Dacian Cioloș of the liberal Renew Europe.

“The names of portfolios are different than before, some are easy but others are a bit confusing," an S&D official with knowledge of the meeting said. “The priority for us now is to see if all important policy areas are covered and that responsibilities are clear.”

Officials from the major political groups said they would start work on assessing backgrounds and portfolios of commissioners at internal meetings planned for the coming days.

At a press conference earlier in the day, von der Leyen presented a gender-balanced team of three executive vice presidents, five vice presidents and 18 commissioners, some with grand-sounding portfolios such as "democracy and demography," and "economy that works for people."

All of them will need to face a parliamentary hearing or hearings, and MEPs can — and have in the past — reject candidates.

Though the exact timetable of the hearings will only be finalized by senior MEPs next week, the hearings will start on September 30 before a final vote on the entire team at a plenary session in October.

MEPs will also send written questions to commissioners before they grill them in person. Before any of it can begin, the Parliament's legal affairs committee must declare that none of the candidates have a potential conflict of interest.

Under Parliament rules, the assembly evaluates commissioners-designate “based on their general competence, European commitment and personal independence.”

“It shall assess knowledge of their prospective portfolio and their communication skills,” the rules say.

Parliament rules require a majority of at least two-thirds among the most influential MEPs — the political groups' so-called coordinators in each committee — for the candidates to pass immediately. That means that commissioners-designate need the support of more political groups than von der Leyen herself managed to secure at her election in July.

“If coordinators cannot reach a majority of at least two-thirds of the committee membership to approve the candidate,” the rules say, a candidate will have to answer additional questions in written form or could even have to reappear before the committee. If even in that event there is no two-thirds majority, a simple majority in a full committee vote would technically be enough for the commissioner candidate to pass.

Officials from the major political groups said they would start work on assessing backgrounds and portfolios of commissioners at internal meetings planned for the coming days.

Good and bad

Von der Leyen’s announcement of her team prompted praise for her focus on gender balance and green issues. But it also sparked confusion and anger, especially over the job title given to Greece's Margaritis Schinas — “protecting the European way of life.”

"The very point about the European way of life is the freedom for individuals to choose their own way of life,” said Sophie in 't Veld, a Dutch MEP from Renew Europe. “We do not need a commissioner for that, thank you very much."

"The implication that Europeans need to be protected from external cultures is grotesque and this narrative should be rejected,” in 't Veld said.

Others have concerns about controversial names in the new team, including László Trócsányi, the Hungarian nominee who was given the neighborhood and enlargement portfolio. He's not a member of the country’s ruling Fidesz party, but he is perceived as loyal to Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and was his justice minister at a time when critics say the government worked to undermine checks and balances.

Criticisms were directly targeted at individual commissioners' backgrounds and past work.

Members of Hungary's opposition Democratic Coalition (part of the S&D) will "do everything so that László Trócsányi won’t be a member of the European Commission,” MEP Csaba Molnár wrote in a statement on behalf of the Hungarian party.

Another controversial name is Rovana Plumb, the Romanian candidate given the transport portfolio, who is seen as close to Liviu Dragnea, the former leader of the governing Social Democratic Party (PSD) imprisoned in May in a case involving fake jobs for party workers.

On Monday, the Romanian delegation in Renew Europe said they would vote against Plumb because of her “questionable integrity,” said one group official.

“She had anti-EU positions and she was a supporter from her public office of Liviu Dragnea,” the official said.

Janusz Wojciechowski, the Polish candidate in charge of the agriculture portfolio, is another name that's causing concern in the Parliament. A member of Poland’s ruling PiS — a party that has repeatedly clashed with the European institutions — he is under investigation by the EU anti-fraud office, OLAF, for alleged irregularities in the reimbursement of travel expenses when he was an MEP between 2004-2014.

Then there's Sylvie Goulard, who on Tuesday was nominated for the internal market job and also interviewed by French police as part of an ongoing investigation over alleged misuse of EU funds by her former party.

Other criticisms were directly targeted at individual commissioners' backgrounds and past work.

Markus Ferber, the EPP group's spokesman on the Parliament's Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee, said former Italian PM Paolo Gentiloni, who was named economy commissioner, did "not manage to get the Italian economy out of the doldrums."

“This kind of track record does not instill a lot of confidence that he will do better as commissioner for the economy," he added.

On the appointment of Margrethe Vestager as vice president for digital and also as competition commissioner, Ferber added that “even after five years in office, competition rules are still not up to speed to deal with the challenges of the digital world.”

Lili Bayer contributed reporting.
description: MEPs need to give their approval to von der Leyen’s team — and some already look in trouble.
